div.p: Mariachi Plaza is the epicenter of Boyle Height’s rich Mexican-American culture. Bounded by three streets, Mariachi Plaza has become a communal space for neighborhoods on East First Street, North Boyle Avenue, and Pleasant Avenue. Since the 1930’s it has functioned as a gathering site for Mariachi musicians in search of work. Today men and women dressed in traditional charro outfits may be spotted entertaining the public with their melodies. Besides providing Mariachi services, the plaza is a center for recreation and commerce. People can purchase goods, food, as well as arts and crafts at the restaurants, shops, and farmers market. People are welcome to walk around and admire the colorfully painted murals located nearby. They may also partake in the community-oriented celebrations, festivals, performances, and events. Essentially, Mariachi Plaza is an example of how communities in Boyle Heights use public space to cater to their social, economic, and cultural needs.

note.p: Mariachi Plaza is the epicenter of Boyle Height’s Mexican-American culture. A space used to address social, economic, and cultural needs.
